diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. It can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs, often leading to acute pericarditis and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infections
diagnoses.description: Various viruses can lead to symptoms such as acute pericarditis and thrombocytopenia. Common viruses include Coxsackievirus, Echovirus, and HIV.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also cause pericarditis and pericardial effusion due to inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Cancer
diagnoses.description: Certain cancers, especially blood cancers like leukemia and lymphomas, can present with thrombocytopenia and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Scurvy
diagnoses.description: A disease resulting from a lack of Vitamin C. It can manifest with follicular hyperkeratosis and sometimes thrombocytopenia due to its effect on blood vessels.

diagnoses.name: Uremia
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from advanced kidney failure. It can lead to pericarditis and pericardial effusion due to the buildup of urea and other waste products.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Thyroid hormone deficiency can result in pericardial effusion and also contribute to non-specific symptoms including changes in skin texture like hyperkeratosis.

diagnoses.name: Medication-Induced
diagnoses.description: Some medications can cause pericarditis, pericardial effusion, and thrombocytopenia as side effects. It's essential to review patient medications in the diagnostic process.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: Though primarily a respiratory illness, TB can spread and cause pericarditis (in severe cases, leading to pericardial effusion) and impact the bone marrow, causing thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: An acute, febrile illness primarily occurring in children. It can lead to coronary artery aneurysms, and, in some cases, it has been associated with pericardial effusion and thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) due to Glomerulonephritis

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with fever, oral ulcers, pericarditis, pleural effusion, and proteinuria, indicating systemic involvement.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily known as a joint disorder, RA can have systemic manifestations including pericarditis and pleurisy, and rarely oral ulcers and renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: This condition is characterized by features of several autoimmune diseases including SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis, and can present with the symptoms listed.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Known primarily for its oral ulcers, it can also involve systemic symptoms including fever and less commonly, pericarditis and renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Can cause fever and can indirectly lead to renal damage (proteinuria) through immune complex deposition, and rarely, can involve pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Viral Myocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Certain viral infections could lead to myocarditis that progresses to pericarditis, with some cases presenting with pleural effusions. Fever is a common symptom.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.rationale: Affects multiple organ systems and can cause fever, pleural effusion, and pericarditis, with renal involvement occasionally leading to proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: A multisystem inflammatory disease that can cause fever, pulmonary involvement (pleural effusion), and pericarditis, with renal involvement rare but possible.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
diagnoses.rationale: Can present with systemic symptoms including fever, renal involvement (proteinuria), and rarer, pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: HIV infection can manifest a wide range of symptoms including fever, oral ulcers, renal involvement, and less commonly, pericardial and pleural effusions.

diagnoses: Immunodeficiency disorders, such as Common Variable Immunodeficiency (CVID)
Autoimmune diseases (e.g., Systemic Lupus Erythematosus, Rheumatoid Arthritis)

diagnoses.name: Iron deficiency anemia
diagnoses.reasoning: Iron deficiency can cause restless legs syndrome, contributing to symptoms like tinnitus and fatigue, which relates to hypoglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: While primarily related to hyperglycemia, episodes of hypoglycemia can occur, especially in treated patients. Diabetes can lead to peripheral edema and nerve damage causing symptoms like tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reasoning: Hypothyroidism can cause a broad spectrum of symptoms including constipation, hypoglycemia, edema, and less commonly, tinnitus and restless legs.

diagnoses.name: Kidney disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Impaired kidney function can lead to fluid retention causing edema, disturbances in electrolyte balance contributing to restless legs and tinnitus, and alterations in glucose handling.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral neuropathy
diagnoses.reasoning: While more of a symptom in itself, underlying causes of peripheral neuropathy like diabetes can cause tinnitus, hypoglycemic events, and restless legs syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Venous insufficiency
diagnoses.reasoning: Venous insufficiency can cause migratory edema and restless legs syndrome. It doesn't directly cause tinnitus but may share common risk factors with conditions that do.

diagnoses.name: Chronic liver disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Liver disease can lead to a variety of systemic symptoms, including edema and hypoglycemia. Tinnitus and restless legs could be related to the associated metabolic disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Heart failure
diagnoses.reasoning: Heart failure can cause fluid retention leading to edema, while associated circulatory issues can lead to restless legs. Hypoglycemia might relate indirectly through dietary and medication effects.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.reasoning: Fibromyalgia could potentially contribute to a wide range of symptoms due to its effect on the nervous system, including restless legs and tinnitus, though it's less directly associated with edema and hypoglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Multiple sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.reasoning: MS can cause a wide array of neurological symptoms due to demyelination in the CNS, potentially including tinnitus and sensations mimicking restless legs syndrome, though it's less directly linked to the other symptoms.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Spinal disorders (e.g., lumbar disc herniation, degenerative disc disease)
Metabolic syndrome (linked to obstructive sleep apnea)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Cancer (e.g., lymphoma or lung cancer, given the lymphadenitis)
Graves' Disease (for hyperthyroidism, can go along with telangiectasias)
Sjögren's Syndrome (can cause lymphadenopathy and dysgeusia)
Rheumatoid Arthritis (can sometimes lead to lymphadenopathy and arteriovenous malformations)
Neurofibromatosis (especially Type 1, can be associated with arteriovenous malformations)
Lymphoma (can cause lymphadenopathy and dysgeusia indirectly due to systemic involvement)
Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (can sometimes result in lymphadenopathy and arteriovenous malformations)
Behçet's Disease (can involve vascular and mucosal abnormalities leading to symptoms like dysgeusia and possibly arteriovenous malformations)
Psychological or psychiatric conditions causing somatic symptoms
Infections causing reactive thrombocytosis and skin manifestations
Severe allergic reaction (not classified as anaphylaxis)
Pheochromocytoma (in rare cases can present with these symptoms)
Insect bite or sting causing a systemic reaction
Acute abdomen (e.g., appendicitis, diverticulitis, ectopic pregnancy)
Poisoning or Toxic Reaction (e.g., chemical, drug overdose)
Neurogenic Shock (due to spinal cord injury or disease)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms such as weakness, aphasia, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a minibar, a temporary blockage of blood flow to the brain, causing stroke-like symptoms that usually resolve within 24 hours.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain, presenting with symptoms like headache, speech difficulties, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that affects the central nervous system, leading to symptoms such as muscle weakness, problems with coordination and balance, and speech difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves neurological phenomena (aura) like visual disturbances followed by a severe headache.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain often caused by a viral infection leading to symptoms including headache, fever, confusion, and in severe cases, problems with speech or weakness.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known as the meninges. Symptoms include severe headache, fever, confusion, and in some instances, aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus that develops in the brain due to an infection, presenting symptoms like headache, fever, speech difficulties, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Some forms can present with aphasia or post-seizure weakness.

diagnoses.name: Hemorrhagic Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when a blood vessel in the brain bursts, leaking blood into the surrounding brain tissue and causing symptoms such as severe headache, weakness, and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with discoid rash, nonscarring alopecia, synovitis (joint pain and swelling), oral ulcers, and in more severe cases, seizures due to central nervous system involvement.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus, Discoid
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized by a chronic skin rash, usually discoid rash. While it's more limited in scope compared to SLE, patients can occasionally exhibit some systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily affects joints causing synovitis but can have systemic manifestations. Skin and neurological manifestations like seizures are less common but can occur especially in severe, untreated disease.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune condition known primarily for causing dry eyes and dry mouth but can also lead to nonscarring alopecia, and in rare cases, systemic involvement including central nervous system manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: This disease shares features with systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. Patients may present with oral ulcers, nonscarring alopecia, and joint pain but seizures are less common.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.rationale: Although more known for skin tightening and sclerosis, systemic sclerosis can involve the entire body, including the joints (synovitis) and, in rare cases, the central nervous system, leading to seizures.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body, including oral ulcers. Joint symptoms, skin manifestations, and neurological involvement including seizures can occur.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and skin rash. Patients might exhibit symptoms like those listed due to overlapping autoimmune pathways, although seizures are uncommon.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: An inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis which may present with skin and joint symptoms. Oral ulcers and seizures are not typically associated but can occur in complex cases.

diagnoses.name: Hashimoto's Thyroiditis
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily affecting the thyroid, this autoimmune disorder can have wide-ranging systemic effects due to hormonal imbalances. Skin and neurological symptoms like seizures can occur, albeit less commonly.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including skin rashes, hair loss, and neurological symptoms such as seizures.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease known for its distinctive skin rash and muscle weakness, which may sometimes involve changes in skin pigmentation and hair loss.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: A disease that leads to inflammation, usually in your lungs, skin, or lymph nodes. It can cause skin discoloration and rashes, hair loss, and neurological complications including seizures.

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune condition that causes the rapid buildup of skin cells, leading to scaling on the skin's surface. In severe cases, it can lead to psoriatic arthritis and is associated with other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lichen Planopilaris
diagnoses.description: A form of lichen planus affecting the scalp, leading to patchy hair loss and can also cause skin discoloration in the affected areas.

diagnoses.name: Discoid Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic skin condition of sores with inflammation and scarring favoring the face, ears, and scalp and occasionally the body. It can lead to dyspigmentation and hair loss in the lesions.

diagnoses.name: Frontal Fibrosing Alopecia
diagnoses.description: A condition causing hair loss and scarring on the scalp near the forehead. The skin in the affected area may show signs of discoloration.

diagnoses.name: Tinea Capitis
diagnoses.description: A fungal infection of the scalp, causing hair loss, scaling, and sometimes discoloration of the skin.

diagnoses.name: Seborrheic Dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A skin condition causing scaly patches, red skin and stubborn dandruff. It can also affect the face, sides of the nose, eyebrows, ears, eyelids, and chest.

diagnoses.name: Pityriasis Amiantacea
diagnoses.description: A rare skin disorder that causes thick, crusty scales that can lead to hair loss and discoloration of the scalp.

diagnoses: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's granulomatosis)
Viral infections (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis C, Dengue fever)
Lupus erythematosus with systemic involvement and CNS manifestation
